conductor.title: Musical Director
conductor.name: Morven Bell
description: Morven's musical education began at primary school in Edinburgh and culminated in graduating from the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama (now the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland) in Glasgow with a BA (Musical Performance) and a Certificate in Postgraduate Studies in Oboe and Cor Anglais.

Since leaving college, Morven has freelanced with most of the major Scottish orchestras, as well as some of the touring musical productions, including Les Misérables and the Fiddler on the Roof national tour. She now prefers to concentrate on the many diverse local gigs available. She is very proud to have played with the HM Royal Marine Band (Scotland).

She has a wide experience of musical teaching and orchestral coaching. She currently teaches oboe (and bassoon) at George Heriot's School, the Edinburgh Academy and Merchiston Castle School, as well as a number of private pupils of all ages.

Her experience of conducting EUWB has led her conducting the Merchiston Castle School wind band, assisting the GHS Junior School Wind Ensemble and being asked to occasionally conduct other local communit wind bands. Morven has been involved with the Edinburgh University Wind Band (or Edinburgh University Wind Ensemble as it was then known) since 1990, first as a player, then as Assistant Conductor and since 1993 as Musical Director.

Mo, as she is known to the band, had an amazing 25th year with band and had such fun celebrating with banders old and new. This academic year sees band celebrating 20 years of our first annual tour and she is very much looking forward to our first concert in Newcastle with Bede Wind and then onwards to Brussels.

I am thrilled to welcome you all to EUWB’s winter concert! Band had a very successful recruitment drive back at the fresher’s fair in September which has taken us from strength to strength, resulting in us having over 100 registered members. This semester, along with our weekly rehearsals, we ran many successful social events including our Sectional meals, an exciting Stags' and Hens’ Pub crawl and of course our annual weekend away to Loch Lochy in the Scottish Highlands.

We are now looking forward to next semester and are already getting excited for our Scratch Rehearsal and Joint Societies Ceilidh in February with Brass Band, Clarinet Choir and Female Voice Choir. For our annual Tour this summer everyone is excited to be taking in the sights of Brussels , Belgium as well as entertaining our European audience at two concerts

pieces.title: Fanfare — Flight to the Unknown World
description: Yagisawa wrote this piece for a friend whose concert band was celebrating its anniversary. It features fanfare and chorale sections, using each instrument of the band to great effect.

pieces.title: Battle of Britain
description: Featuring music from the 1969 film of the same name, 'Battle of Britain' features the popular march 'Aces High', originally the opening 'Luftwaffe March' in the score. The music was written to replace the first version of the score by Sir William Walton which was deemed to be unsuitable by the producers for being too overtly patriotic. 'Aces High' is followed by other themes from the film, finishing with its main theme.

Ron Goodwin was an English composer, particularly known for film scores such as those for 'Where Eagles Dare' and '633 Squadron'. Darrol Barry is better known for his brass band transcriptions and arrangements. He sadly passed away on 6th June this year.

pieces.title: The Eve of the War
pieces.subtitle: From "Jeff Wayne's Musical Version of 'The War of the Worlds'"
description: "No one would have believed in the last years of the nineteenth century that human affairs were being watched from the timeless worlds of space..."

Written in 1978 for Jeff Wayne's progressive rock concept album adapting H. G. Wells' novel 'The War of the Worlds', 'Eve of the War' depicts the initial arrival of the Martian tripods on a planet which had previously stated that "the chances of anything coming from Mars are a million to one". In 2009, the album became the 40th bestselling album in the UK of all time.

pieces.title: A Bernstein Tribute
description: This tribute features music from Bernstein's 'West Side Story' (including "Prologue", "Somewhere", "Scherzo" and "Mambo") and from 'On the Town' ("The Great Lover", "Times Square: 1944" and "Lonely Town"). It is arranged by the American Clare Grundman, who is better known to the band for having written tour favourite 'The Hebrides Suite'.

pieces.title: Symphonic Dances
pieces.subtitle: From 'Fiddler on the Roof'
description: The 1964 musical 'Fiddler on the Roof' depicts its main character Tevye's struggle to reconcile the traditions of his faith and his people with the changing world around him in 1900s Imperial Russia, including the desire of his daughters to marry for love and the pogrom from which they are eventually forced to flee. The score marries the Jewish klezmer style of music with modern western musical theatre constructs.
'Symphonic Dances' features some of the dances from the musical, including the opening number 'Tradition', 'The Bottle Dance', 'Perchik and Hodel Dance', 'Chava Sequence' and 'To Life (L'chaim).

pieces.title: The Magnificent Seven
description: The music from the 1960 Western film of the same name, 'The Magnificent Seven' is an instantly recognisable theme due to its having been used several times in popular media since. The film was a remake for western audiences of a Japanese film 'The Seven Samurai' and featured stars such as Steve McQueen and Yul Brynner.
Elmer Bernstein (who was not related in any way to Leonard) composed over 150 musical scores for films and television, including those of 'Ghostbusters' and 'The Black Cauldron'.

pieces.title: James Bond 007
description: Featuring the main theme by John Barry, 'All Time High', 'For Your Eyes Only' and 'Goldfinger', this arrangement covers several of the most memorable themes from the James Bond films. Its arranger, Johan de Meij, is better known to the band for having arranged EUWB favourite 'Moment for Morricone'.

pieces.title: Pentland Hills
description: Named after the hills to the south-west of Edinburgh, 'Pentland Hills' features several traditional Scottish songs, including 'The Rowan Tree' among others.

pieces.title: Loch Lomond
description: Originally published in 1841, "The Bonnie Banks o' Loch Lomond" is a traditional Scottish song, the current lyrics for which are thought to be a lament after the Battle of Culloden in 1745 for those who had been lost in the rebellion and those who had been subsequently executed by the English.
This arrangement marries the main theme with that of 'Londonderry Air' in its last section, which works to great effect.

pieces.title: Mr. Blue Sky
description: 'Mr. Blue Sky' was written in 1977 for the Electric Light Orchestra (ELO) by its frontman Jeff Lynne. It is reported to have been written after Lynne spent two weeks in a chalet in Switzerland trying to write an album during which it was entirely dark and misty, until suddenly it cleared and he was struck with how beautiful the Alps were. It has been used several times in popular media, including 'Guardians of the Galaxy, Vol. 2'. The original track finished the first side of the record, thus the often misheard final line "Please turn me over!", played in this arrangement on the glockenspiel.

raffle.stream: Raffle: We are raising money for the Samaritans (SC040604) and Drake Music Scotland (SC026908)!
